title: Negation-Induced Forgetting in LLMs
author: Francesca Capuano (University of Tübingen), Ellen Boschert (University of Tübingen), Barbara Kaup (University of Tübingen), ... ,
relevance_why: The study explores cognitive phenomena in large language models, which could inform models applied in audio processing, especially in understanding memory representations.
background: Investigating how Large Language Models respond to negation and whether they exhibit memory biases similar to humans.
contribution: This paper introduces an experimental framework to assess negation-induced forgetting in LLMs, demonstrating that specific models can exhibit this cognitive bias.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous research primarily focused on human subjects regarding negation-induced forgetting without examining LLMs.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work adapts human cognitive experiments to LLMs, revealing potential similarities in cognitive biases.

key_innovation: The study uses a structured experimental setup to test memory biases in LLMs, specifically under negation scenarios.
real_world_impact: Understanding NIF in LLMs could enhance the deployment of AI in contexts where accurate recall is crucial, like legal or educational applications.
limitations: Limited to specific proprietary models, restricting generalizability to other LLMs.

new_terms.negation-induced forgetting: **Negation-induced forgetting (NIF)** is a phenomenon where negating incorrect information leads to greater memory impairment compared to affirming correct information.

open_sourcing: Data and analysis scripts are available on OSF.
